trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: An comparison between the generally available Azure AD and the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: An comparison between the generally available Azure AD and the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: App model v2.0 preview: What's different?
trans-unit.target: App model v2.0 preview: What's different?

trans-unit.source: If you're familiar with the generally available Azure AD service or have integrated apps with Azure AD in the past, there may be some differences in the v2.0 app model that you would not expect.
trans-unit.target: If you're familiar with the generally available Azure AD service or have integrated apps with Azure AD in the past, there may be some differences in the v2.0 app model that you would not expect.

trans-unit.source: This document calls out those differences for your understanding.
trans-unit.target: This document calls out those differences for your understanding.

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD Accounts
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD Accounts

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model allows developers to write apps that accept sign-in from both Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD accounts, using a single endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model allows developers to write apps that accept sign-in from both Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD accounts, using a single endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This gives you the ability to write your app completely account-agnostic; it can be ignorant of the type of account that the user signs in with.
trans-unit.target: This gives you the ability to write your app completely account-agnostic; it can be ignorant of the type of account that the user signs in with.

trans-unit.source: Of course, you *can* make your app aware of the type of account being used in a particular session, but you don't have to.
trans-unit.target: Of course, you *can* make your app aware of the type of account being used in a particular session, but you don't have to.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if your app calls the [Office 365 REST APIs](https://www.msdn.com/office/office365/howto/authenticate-Office-365-APIs-using-v2), some additional functionality and data will be available to enterprise users, such as their SharePoint sites or Directory data.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if your app calls the [Office 365 REST APIs](https://www.msdn.com/office/office365/howto/authenticate-Office-365-APIs-using-v2), some additional functionality and data will be available to enterprise users, such as their SharePoint sites or Directory data.

trans-unit.source: But for many actions, such as [Reading a user's mail](https://www.msdn.com/office/office365/howto/authenticate-Office-365-APIs-using-v2), the code can be written exactly the same for both Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD accounts.
trans-unit.target: But for many actions, such as [Reading a user's mail](https://www.msdn.com/office/office365/howto/authenticate-Office-365-APIs-using-v2), the code can be written exactly the same for both Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD accounts.

trans-unit.source: Integrating your app with Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD accounts is now one simple process.
trans-unit.target: Integrating your app with Microsoft Accounts and Azure AD accounts is now one simple process.

trans-unit.source: You can use a single set of endpoints, a single library, and a single app registration to gain access to both the consumer and enterprise worlds.
trans-unit.target: You can use a single set of endpoints, a single library, and a single app registration to gain access to both the consumer and enterprise worlds.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the v2.0 app model preview, check out [the overview](active-directory-appmodel-v2-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the v2.0 app model preview, check out [the overview](active-directory-appmodel-v2-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: New App Registration Portal
trans-unit.target: New App Registration Portal

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model requires you to register your Microsoft apps in a new location: [apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com).
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model requires you to register your Microsoft apps in a new location: [apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com).

trans-unit.source: This is the portal where you can obtain an Application Id, customize the appearance of your app's sign-in page, and more.
trans-unit.target: This is the portal where you can obtain an Application Id, customize the appearance of your app's sign-in page, and more.

trans-unit.source: We will continue to add more and more functionality to this App Registration Portal, largely based on feedback we receive during the preview.
trans-unit.target: We will continue to add more and more functionality to this App Registration Portal, largely based on feedback we receive during the preview.

trans-unit.source: The intent is that this portal will be the new location where you can go to manage anything and everything having to do with your Microsoft apps.
trans-unit.target: The intent is that this portal will be the new location where you can go to manage anything and everything having to do with your Microsoft apps.

trans-unit.source: And the best part is, you don't need an Azure or Office subscription to use it.
trans-unit.target: And the best part is, you don't need an Azure or Office subscription to use it.

trans-unit.source: All you need is a personal Microsoft account or a work/school account.
trans-unit.target: All you need is a personal Microsoft account or a work/school account.

trans-unit.source: Note that today, apps registered in the new App Registration Portal will only work with app model v2.0, and *only* apps registered in the new App Registration Portal will work with the app model v2.0.
trans-unit.target: Note that today, apps registered in the new App Registration Portal will only work with app model v2.0, and *only* apps registered in the new App Registration Portal will work with the app model v2.0.

trans-unit.source: If you try to use one of these apps with the generally available Microsoft Account or Azure AD services, or try to use an existing app with the v2.0 app model, you may run into incompatibilities.
trans-unit.target: If you try to use one of these apps with the generally available Microsoft Account or Azure AD services, or try to use an existing app with the v2.0 app model, you may run into incompatibilities.

trans-unit.source: One App Id for All Platforms
trans-unit.target: One App Id for All Platforms

trans-unit.source: In the GA Azure AD service, you may have registered several different apps for a single project.
trans-unit.target: In the GA Azure AD service, you may have registered several different apps for a single project.

trans-unit.source: You were forced to use separate app registrations for your native clients and web apps:
trans-unit.target: You were forced to use separate app registrations for your native clients and web apps:

trans-unit.source: Old Application Registration UI
trans-unit.target: Old Application Registration UI

trans-unit.source: For example, if you've built both a website and an iOS app, you had to register them separately, using two different Application Ids.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you've built both a website and an iOS app, you had to register them separately, using two different Application Ids.

trans-unit.source: If you had a website and a backend web api, you might have registered each as a separate app in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: If you had a website and a backend web api, you might have registered each as a separate app in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: If you had an iOS app and an Android app, you also might have registered two different apps.
trans-unit.target: If you had an iOS app and an Android app, you also might have registered two different apps.

trans-unit.source: Now, all you need is a single app registration and a single Application Id for each of your projects.
trans-unit.target: Now, all you need is a single app registration and a single Application Id for each of your projects.

trans-unit.source: You can add several "platforms" to a each project, and provide the appropriate data for each platform you add.
trans-unit.target: You can add several "platforms" to a each project, and provide the appropriate data for each platform you add.

trans-unit.source: Of course, you can create as many apps as you like depending on your requirements, but for the majority of cases only one Application Id should be necessary.
trans-unit.target: Of course, you can create as many apps as you like depending on your requirements, but for the majority of cases only one Application Id should be necessary.

trans-unit.source: Our aim is that this will lead to a more simplified app management and development experience, and create a more consolidated view of a single project that you might be working on.
trans-unit.target: Our aim is that this will lead to a more simplified app management and development experience, and create a more consolidated view of a single project that you might be working on.

trans-unit.source: Scopes, Not Resources
trans-unit.target: Scopes, Not Resources

trans-unit.source: In the Azure AD generally available service, an app can behave as a **resource**, or a recipient of tokens.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure AD generally available service, an app can behave as a **resource**, or a recipient of tokens.

trans-unit.source: A resource can define a number of **scopes** or **oAuth2Permissions** that it understands, allowing client apps to request tokens to that resource for a certain set of scopes.
trans-unit.target: A resource can define a number of **scopes** or **oAuth2Permissions** that it understands, allowing client apps to request tokens to that resource for a certain set of scopes.

trans-unit.source: Consider the Azure AD Graph API as an example of a resource:
trans-unit.target: Consider the Azure AD Graph API as an example of a resource:

trans-unit.source: Resource Identifier, or `AppID URI`: `https://graph.windows.net/`
trans-unit.target: Resource Identifier, or `AppID URI`: `https://graph.windows.net/`

trans-unit.source: Scopes, or `OAuth2Permissions`: `Directory.Read`, `Directory.Write`, etc.
trans-unit.target: Scopes, or `OAuth2Permissions`: `Directory.Read`, `Directory.Write`, etc.

trans-unit.source: All of this holds true for the v2.0 app model.
trans-unit.target: All of this holds true for the v2.0 app model.

trans-unit.source: An app can still behave as resource, define scopes, and be identified by a URI.
trans-unit.target: An app can still behave as resource, define scopes, and be identified by a URI.

trans-unit.source: Client apps can still request access to those scopes.
trans-unit.target: Client apps can still request access to those scopes.

trans-unit.source: However, the way in which a client requests those permissions has changed.
trans-unit.target: However, the way in which a client requests those permissions has changed.

trans-unit.source: Incremental and Dynamic Consent
trans-unit.target: Incremental and Dynamic Consent

trans-unit.source: Apps registered in the generally available Azure AD service needed to specify their required OAuth 2.0 permissions in the Azure Portal, at app creation time:
trans-unit.target: Apps registered in the generally available Azure AD service needed to specify their required OAuth 2.0 permissions in the Azure Portal, at app creation time:

trans-unit.source: Permissions Registration UI
trans-unit.target: Permissions Registration UI

trans-unit.source: The permissions an app required were configured **statically**.
trans-unit.target: The permissions an app required were configured **statically**.

trans-unit.source: While this allowed configuration of the app to exist in the Azure Portal and kept the code nice and simple, it presents a few issues for developers:
trans-unit.target: While this allowed configuration of the app to exist in the Azure Portal and kept the code nice and simple, it presents a few issues for developers:

trans-unit.source: An app had to know all of the permissions it would ever need at app creation time.
trans-unit.target: An app had to know all of the permissions it would ever need at app creation time.

trans-unit.source: Adding permissions over time was a difficult process.
trans-unit.target: Adding permissions over time was a difficult process.

trans-unit.source: An app had to know all of the resources it would ever access ahead of time.
trans-unit.target: An app had to know all of the resources it would ever access ahead of time.

trans-unit.source: It was difficult to create apps that could access an arbitrary number of resources.
trans-unit.target: It was difficult to create apps that could access an arbitrary number of resources.

trans-unit.source: An app had to request all the permissions it would ever need upon the user's first sign-in.
trans-unit.target: An app had to request all the permissions it would ever need upon the user's first sign-in.

trans-unit.source: In some cases this led to a very long list of permissions, which discouraged end-users from approving the app's access on initial sign-in.
trans-unit.target: In some cases this led to a very long list of permissions, which discouraged end-users from approving the app's access on initial sign-in.

trans-unit.source: In the v2.0 app model, you can specify the permissions your app needs **dynamically**, at runtime, during regular usage of your app.
trans-unit.target: In the v2.0 app model, you can specify the permissions your app needs **dynamically**, at runtime, during regular usage of your app.

trans-unit.source: If the user has consented to those permissions in the past for this particular app, they will simply enter their credentials and be signed into the app.

trans-unit.source: If the user has not consented to any of these permissions, the v2.0 endpoint will ask the user for consent to those permissions.
trans-unit.target: If the user has not consented to any of these permissions, the v2.0 endpoint will ask the user for consent to those permissions.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, you can read up on [permissions, consent, and scopes](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more, you can read up on [permissions, consent, and scopes](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).

trans-unit.source: Allowing an app to request permissions dynamically via the `scope` parameter gives you full control over your user's experience.
trans-unit.target: Allowing an app to request permissions dynamically via the `scope` parameter gives you full control over your user's experience.

trans-unit.source: If you wish, you can choose to frontload your consent experience and ask for all permissions in one initial authorization request.
trans-unit.target: If you wish, you can choose to frontload your consent experience and ask for all permissions in one initial authorization request.

trans-unit.source: Or if your app requires a large number of permissions, you can choose to gather those permissions from the user incrementally, as they attempt to use certain features of your app over time.
trans-unit.target: Or if your app requires a large number of permissions, you can choose to gather those permissions from the user incrementally, as they attempt to use certain features of your app over time.

trans-unit.source: Offline Access
trans-unit.target: Offline Access

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model introduces a new well-known permission for apps - the `offline_access` scope.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model introduces a new well-known permission for apps - the `offline_access` scope.

trans-unit.source: All apps will need to request this permission if they need to access resources on the behalf of a user for a prolonged period of time, even when the user may not be actively using the app.
trans-unit.target: All apps will need to request this permission if they need to access resources on the behalf of a user for a prolonged period of time, even when the user may not be actively using the app.

trans-unit.source: The `offline_access` scope will appear to the user in consent dialogs as "Access your data offline", which the user must agree to.
trans-unit.target: The `offline_access` scope will appear to the user in consent dialogs as "Access your data offline", which the user must agree to.

trans-unit.source: Requesting the `offline_access` permission will enable your web app to receive OAuth 2.0 refresh_tokens from the v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Requesting the `offline_access` permission will enable your web app to receive OAuth 2.0 refresh_tokens from the v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Refresh_tokens are long-lived, and can be exchanged for new OAuth 2.0 access_tokens for extended periods of access.
trans-unit.target: Refresh_tokens are long-lived, and can be exchanged for new OAuth 2.0 access_tokens for extended periods of access.

trans-unit.source: If your app does not request the `offline_access` scope, it will not receive refresh_tokens.
trans-unit.target: If your app does not request the `offline_access` scope, it will not receive refresh_tokens.

trans-unit.source: This means that when you redeem an authorization_code in the [OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#oauth2-authorization-code-flow), you will only receive back an access_token from the `/oauth2/token` endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This means that when you redeem an authorization_code in the [OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#oauth2-authorization-code-flow), you will only receive back an access_token from the `/oauth2/token` endpoint.

trans-unit.source: That access_token will remain valid for a short period of time (typically one hour), but will eventually expire.
trans-unit.target: That access_token will remain valid for a short period of time (typically one hour), but will eventually expire.

trans-unit.source: At that point in time, your app will need to redirect the user back to the `/oauth2/authorize` endpoint to retrieve a new authorization_code.
trans-unit.target: At that point in time, your app will need to redirect the user back to the `/oauth2/authorize` endpoint to retrieve a new authorization_code.

trans-unit.source: During this redirect, the user may or may not need to enter their credentials again or re-consent to permissions, depending on the the type of app.
trans-unit.target: During this redirect, the user may or may not need to enter their credentials again or re-consent to permissions, depending on the the type of app.

trans-unit.target: To learn more about OAuth 2.0, refresh_tokens, and access_tokens, check out the [v2.0 app model protocol reference](active-directory-v2-protocols.md).

trans-unit.source: Token Claims
trans-unit.target: Token Claims

trans-unit.source: The claims in tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint will not be identical to tokens issued by the generally available Azure AD endpoints - apps migrating to the new service should not assume a particular claim will exist in id_tokens or access_tokens.
trans-unit.target: The claims in tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint will not be identical to tokens issued by the generally available Azure AD endpoints - apps migrating to the new service should not assume a particular claim will exist in id_tokens or access_tokens.

trans-unit.source: Tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint are compliant with the OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect specifications, but may follow different semantics than the generally available Azure AD service.
trans-unit.target: Tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint are compliant with the OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect specifications, but may follow different semantics than the generally available Azure AD service.

trans-unit.source: To learn about the specific claims emitted in v2.0 app model tokens, see the [v2.0 token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn about the specific claims emitted in v2.0 app model tokens, see the [v2.0 token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).
